content.description: Climb from the dirt trail enjoying a layback on a decent sized flake/crack. Climbs up and right over to the anchors shared with harder route "Freezerburn" that starts to the right.
content.protection: 11 Bolts to 2 anchors: 1 metolius rap anchor and one quick link. ( Rap off)
content.location: The alcove area,  Climbing from the dirt trail right  of the stone saddle....

content.description:
Who's There is a so-so route on the far right-hand side of The Grail. Climb the arête in two pitches, both about 75 feet. The second pitch has a lot of traversing across the top of the feature. This route has a lot of loose rock, so beware.  

  Rappel once from the top of pitch two, directly to the ground on the climber's right, using a 70m rope.
content.protection: Quickdraws and slings for anchors.
content.location: This northwest-facing arête climbs the on the far right-hand side of The Grail. The belay is OFF of the main trail. If you’re belaying on the trail, you are too far left.It is currently the furthest right route on the main wall.

content.description: Squeeze job between Divine Vessel on the left and Homeostasis on the right. So close to both that it detracts from the enjoyment. Awkward clip up high, cool crux, second pitch or extension above..?
content.protection: Maybe 10 bolts, fixed draws at the anchor.
content.location: Locate either classic route on either side, and confirm with the tape on the belay bolt (no hanger). Begins in a shallow dihedral with gaston and sidepull crimps, then moves left past a mini-roof bulge.

climbs.name: The Way of the Peaceful Warrior

content.description:
Fun sidepulls and laybacks on blocky rock takes you to a move way far left from your 4th bolt.  Clip the 5th bolt (long fixed draw as of Nov. 2017) and launch into the crux on incredible rock, with sustained, steep face climbing!  6th bolt is a pain to clip, and takes you away from the natural line, which is more to the right.  Fun steepness the rest of the way. 

  I thought the climbing on this was superb and merits 4 stars, but the bolting is a bit funky.  The rock was a delight, though a bit suspect at the start.
content.protection: Bolts, 5th should be fixed.
content.location: Starts straight from the alcove at chest level, about 50 feet right of the true Grail Alcove.

climbs.name: The Way of the Peaceful Bolter

content.description: Sustained climbing on side-pulls, crimpers, and underclings to a fun cruxy section up and right around a bulge. The difficulty drops off markedly for the last 1/4 of the route, after the last big underclings and small roof. Shares the last two bolts with “Way of the Peaceful Warrior.” Bit of a runout to the chains but the climbing is easy out right.
content.protection: 13 bolts (11 plus 2 shared with Peaceful Warrior). Chains and perma-draws.
content.location: First route as you walk down from the giant pine tree, about 20 feet down from the tree. Way of the Peaceful Warrior (12b) is the line directly to the left. A 70m is required to top-rope these routes.

content.description:
An amazing journey through edges and pockets that takes you epically high up on the Grail. Start as you would for Magnum Opus and then break right just before the first magnum crux to a good ledge rest beneath the main crux section on Voyager 1. Some rad pockets and sparse feet make up the next 2 bolts of business, and then carry on through a sea of ledges and edges (~12a) for a very long time to reach another thin and super unique finishing crux just below the anchor. Even with an 80m rope you will need to lower twice.  

  Extremely tall! Somewhat sporty! Brilliant stone!
content.protection: Many quick draws ... 18?
content.location: Shares the start with Magnum Opus and then breaks right.

content.description: Moderate climbing to rest then Crux 3/4 up to finish.  Bolt could be lower in crux area bit heady.   Fun
content.protection: 11 or 12 bolts
content.location: Right  of homeostasis

content.description: Start on 2 Gray, dishwasher-sized boulders. Shares the 1st bolt with “I’m not dead yet,” then branches right. 5.11b to first anchor. Be careful when lowering from top to first anchor 70M just reaches.

You've probably heard of this route. And for good reason. It's truly incredible. 

  To the left of the little cave, climb up some orange stone and around an arete onto a beautiful blue face and finish up and right to a 2 bolt anchor at a stance. Another option is to climb the pillar right of the cave via a newer route to a nice full on ledge. Both first pitch options are around 11+.  

  Launch from either belay onto the stunning blue headwall. Edge your way to the left side of the slash and follow it up and right through some harder terrain to a memorable runnel finish. Absolutely stellar climbing on world class stone.
content.protection: 12 draws
content.location: To the left of the Grail on the obvious, tall, blue, right facing wall.

content.description: The first pitch heads up nice 5.11 climbing to a 5 ft boulder problem that ends in big jugs. Moderate 5.10 leads to first anchors. The extension or second pitch heads up a LF dihedral in white rock.
content.protection: 20 bolts
content.location: 25 ft left of The Serf

content.description: Starts in a small corner in the chert band then climbs a tricky smooth slap section then the route branches left.  From here it gets steeper on small edges and a pocket here and there, the crux.  Finish off with some nice sculped pinches to the top. Great climb.. The The end
content.protection: Bolts
content.location: Right of The Madness, shares the same start as The Goods but branches left after the slab.

content.description: A Link Up, starting from the dirt trail and clipping the first few bolts of " Whos your Daddy" ...climbing left for several independent and squeezed in bolts to meet up to the finish of " Band Camp"
content.protection: Bolts to  link up with "Band Camp" Anchors
content.location: Climb "Whos your Daddy" to finish on "Band Camp"

content.description:
Sweaty & Guilty. Guilty of:

Being squeezed in between two superior routes (Serf and Naysayer) and thus insulting those climbsHaving poorly located boltsBeing in desperate need of a proper cleaningI'm posting this up mainly to warn people that this route, in its current state, is dangerous. Until it is cleaned of loose holds, flakes, and blocks, it should not be climbed. Even then, consider the third and fourth bolts which are placed very close to (within inches of) the edge of small aretes - these could shear away the rock in these spots (I've seen it happen).

 The climbing itself isn't bad, but the first half of the route may leave you constantly wondering if holds on the neighboring routes are "on". The line becomes more independent in its upper half, but unfortunately the rock quality also deteriorates. Personally, I think this thing should be removed but, at the very least, the job should be finished with some cleaning and some adjustments to the bolting.

 PS: I left the massive resting flake formerly found just after the lone permadraw at the bottom of the climb in case you want to glue it back on. Sorry it's in two pieces but at least my belayer survived.
content.protection: A top rope, a helmet, and a crowbar.

content.description: Fun route with great rock all the way to the top.
content.protection: P1:11d 12 bolts to rings (90') Wandering on nice rock.   P2:11d 10 bolts to rap hangers. More wandering.....   P3:11d More wandering
content.location: First route to the left of Mesquiter.

content.description: Awesome 5.11 climbing to sport anchors. There is a 12c extension that I did not do.
content.protection: Bolts with fixed draws at the top
content.location: just to the right of all the 5.12s in the mesquiter area. There was a small piece of tape on a low bolt identifying the route when I did it.

content.description: 70 meter rope required. 1st anchor makes a great 35 meter 11d. Lots of small cruxes to good rests. Easy to read until a hard finish at first anchor. Keep pulling for another 15 meters on harder to read rock. A few hard clips will lead to more endurance climbing that eases near the finish. Be careful lowering.
content.protection: 26 draws
content.location: Just left of Divine Fury

content.description: Reachy move to a fingerlock down low, then another reach on poor rock gains the lieback dihedral.
content.protection: Bolts
content.location: Just downhill from The Goodness

content.description:
Mellow climbing down low leads to a tricky traverse left. A crux move, or a reachy clip leads you back to the right.  

  Fun climbing leads up a groove which you must exit on the right to reach the anchor.
content.protection: 13 Bolts to lower off biners. I think these are steel!
content.location: This is the nice slab between Khaleesi and the Maddness (Which has the name written at the base).

content.description: Pitch 1 is an awkward 11a for 90 ft about 10 draws. 15 draws for pitch 2 and 3 12c and 11d respectively.
content.protection: Draws
content.location: Between voyager one and divine vessel. Several new lines have been put up in this area. Look for a pillar to a large shark tooth on pitch one.

content.description: Ledgy climbing leads to a steep face near the top.
content.protection: 10 bolts, plus 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This sport route is the last route on the right side of the wall before the arête climb, Who's There. This route is on the right of Eminent Domain and to the left of Who's There. Start on blocky chert left of ground cactus.

content.description: Fun route with a couple extension options.11a/b to first anchors — Reachy move above sloping ledge.11d to the second anchors — Awesome climbing with big moves and holds12b/c to the last set
content.protection: 27 bolts
content.location: Second bolt line left of Raven Nation

content.description: Corner/groove to face, nothing too memorable but still good climbing. A good warm-up if the other 5.10's in the area are crowded.
content.protection: 13 bolts, lower-off anchors.
content.location: Starts off the left side of the small cave that is below Way Of The Peaceful Warrior/Bolter, shares anchors with No Ordinary Moments.

content.description: 3 pitches, all bolted, all pleasant. Try not to rain choss on the masses of people below you, but enjoy your own peace and quiet as well.
content.protection: A good handful of bolts, raps with a single 70.
content.location: Right of 'Sky Club' / 'Vesper/Air France'. Left of Mandate for the Masses.

content.description: Bouldery start to positive face climbing
content.protection: 9 Bolts to rap rings. Rap off
content.location: 40 feet right of the true alcove. Climbs out of a bivvy sized cave about 4 feet above the trail.

content.description: Start up a bulge through some harder-than-expected movement to reach a standing rest and the base of some big pods. From here move through the pods and into the upper headwall, crimping and edging for a WHILE. A long, brilliant route. Sustained.
content.protection: 5 or 6 draws for the beginning, the rest are steel permadraws, hooks at the anchors.

content.description: Orange Limestone, left of " Crusade"  ... this rock is less sharp as the blue areas, and climbs nicely.
content.protection: 10 bolts leads to metolius rap hangers, which have chains and steel biners ( 2015)
content.location: Left of Crusade, in the " Main Wall.” Start on left side of the brown & orange, 8-ft, ground-sitting flake.

content.description: Start on the left side of a pod (just above a little down-climb on the walk into the Grail). The start is shared with Horse Platitudes. Break off to the left when you reach the left facing dihedral at mid-height. A sustained and boulder crux ensues shortly after. Crimp and high step your way to a rest below one last hard move up and left of a pod to the chains.
content.protection: QD's 70 M rope

content.description: Begin to the left of the start of Exclaibur.  Start up through the first two bolts (crux) of improbable climbing through a mono pocket.  Continue upward easily after this to a thin and slightly sharp section through the obvious right-facing corner.  Continue to chains.
content.protection: 8 bolts to bolted anchor equipped for lowering
content.location: To the left of Excalibur

content.description: Climb up and right out of a pod and through some easy (and at time questionable) terrain. A short section of ledges leads to the first crux trending left and to a shared rest with Horse Platitudes. From here enter the routes crux through very tight pockets and small edges. The climbs red point crux then comes several bolts higher with a strange right hand imaginary hold and a big move up and left to a gaston. Carry on to the chains. Only seen 2 repeats at time of writing. Originally suggested as 14a. A brilliant pitch!
content.protection: QD's 70 M rope

content.description: Fun climbing down low with a few thin moves leads up to the obvious corner. Climb the arete and then make powerful moves up the steeper more fractured rock to the right to the anchor.
content.protection: 12 bolts to Hangers with old aluminum biners.
content.location: In the "Blue Goodness" Sector to the right of the Sadness and to the left of The Goodness. The name is written at the base of the route.

content.description:
A fun jaunt up fine features. 

  Starts with moves up a step block to step up on slab.  Follow bigger features and weaknesses up and right to shallow left facing corner.  Up ya go on the steep face for the finish. 

  Fun!
content.protection: Bolted sports route.  8 or 9 draws to bolted anchor.
content.location:
The furthest route to the left on the main Grail wall before rounding the back of the alcove over to Farcical Aquatic Ceremony and the corner of Greyhound. 

  Facing into the alcove, the first route on the right side.

content.description: Very fun climbing on vertical orange rock. Tricky crux at the bulge about ¾ way up.
content.protection: 7 bolts to 3 anchors ( 2 have chains ...2015)
content.location: Left of Flesh Wound...before you hit the 5.12 routes)

content.description: Fun varied climbing through a few changing corners down low and then straight forward pulling on edges with plenty of feet to the chains way up top.
content.protection: 15 bolts
content.location: One route to the left of The Sadness.

content.description: 10d to the first anchor. 5.12 climbing above.  First pitch is ~ 100 ft and a great warm up, especially when the right side of the grail is crowded.
content.protection: Bolts
content.location: As with most routes on the grail, look for the tape marker at the base of the route.

content.description: Begin on The Village Idiot but break off left at the first anchor and follow excellent, sustained climbing to the top of the wall.
content.protection: Many draws. Lower twice with a 70.
content.location: Start as for The Village Idiot.

content.description:
P1: Clip the 1st two bolts of Total Depravity and then angle left into a corner which is followed up and then a little right through the last bolts to a mid-anchor. 12 bolts, 100', 10b/c. 

  P2: Up the corner as it steepens to a headwall of edges. 15 bolts, 110', 12c.
content.protection: bolts
content.location: Approximately the middle of the orange rock portion of the Grail Wall.

content.description: Consistant through the slabby bottom section - this is harder than it appears. A rest mid way leads into the headwall and the route gradually gets tougher until a final series of sculpted amazing pockets in the bulge guarding the chains.
content.protection: QDs 70M rope

content.description: An amazing pitch. A crux down low in some sharper rock leads you to a stance below a beautiful headwall of sculpted edges and ledges. Maybe it's 13a? What do you think? A must do.
content.protection: Many QDs, 80meter rope

content.description: Real good climbing on small crimps, with a few really good shakes.
content.protection: bolts
content.location: It's the route that goes up and right from the anchors of Homeostasis.

content.description: Fight through the initial pump to get to a cozy ledge. Then work your way up to a technical finish. You can get a few good jams in there! 5.11b to the first anchor. The extension continues past another 9 bolts and is excellent. 5.12b
content.protection: 13x Bolts to First Anchor9x More Bolts to Second Anchor
content.location: To the right of Divine Vessel

content.description: HHG climbs into a groove just right of the Raven.  Exit on right (crux) and follow sustained thin climbing to the anchors.
content.protection: 9 bolts
content.location: Just right of the Raven and shares the same anchor

content.description: Start on the left side of a pod - sharing the start with the 12c. This version breaks right at a left facing dihedral at mid height. Climb up a column to a brief rest before a hard exiting boulder problem on small holds and poor feet. Share the anchor with Magnum Opus. Solid in the grade.
content.protection: QD's 70m rope

content.description:
Amazing holds down low lead you to a great rest before the business. Punch it up small holds and pockets to a good rest. 

  The climbing only gets better as sculpted holds lead to the anchor. 

  This route would only be better if it was more sustained. The crux feels much harder than the rest of the route.
content.protection: 13 bolts to lower off biners. The biners might need to replaced or upgraded to steel soon.
content.location: This is the rightmost route in the "Blue Goodness" sector. To the right of Vesper, and to the left of Mesquiter and Honeycomb. It is immediately to the right of The Madness and the bottom can be used to access The The.

content.description: Climbs from the dirt trail, and a small dish on sharp holds, left to a shallow dihedral eventually pulling a small overlap and finishing on the face to the right of "Whos your daddy" ( sharing anchors)
content.protection: 10 Bolts , shared anchors with Whos your Daddy, Rap off
content.location: Right of Whos your daddy. About 20 feet right of the small grey saddle that leads to to the true alcove.

content.description:
This is a pretty fun route that takes you near the top of the Grail Wall.  According to the book, the first pitch is the crux at 5.11d and it’s probably the best pitch of the route.  It sees less traffic above this pitch for sure.  There is definitely some loose rock up high, so keep this in mind if you choose to do this route on a busy day with lots of parties below you.

P1 (5.11d): A fun, steep pitch up edges. 11 bolts, 100’

P2 (5.11b): I felt this was a sandbag.  It’s tough off the belay but the crux comes just after a mantle move when you have to traverse right past 2 bolts to the anchor.  9 bolts, 80’.

P3 (5.11b): This pitch is pretty straightforward and a bit shorter than the others.  7 bolts, 70’

P4 (5.11b): Another long pitch that starts out vertical.  The crux of the pitch is passing a bulge.  Aftwards it turns to a thoughtful slab for a few moves.  Be mindful of a huge, undercut block just left of the bolt line on this pitch.  It’s probably solid, but we didn’t pull on it to find out.

 Rappel the route with a single 60m rope.  On the last rappel, it’s easier to go the Divine Vessel anchors if it’s open.
content.protection: 14 draws + anchor gear
content.location: It’s near the middle of The Grail section of rock.  It’s one route to the left of Divine Vessel, which can be found with “DV” outlined in chalk at the base of the route (as of March ‘19).  DV also has one perma-draw 2/3 of the way up that is pretty easy to spot.

content.description: This route is a long voyage up impeccable gray/blue limestone for 120 ft.  Thin and highly technical climbing on mostly small holds will see you through to the chains.
content.protection: 16 bolts to bolted anchor with chains and leaver biners.  80 meter rope probably mandatory as I didn't have much rope left with mine after lowering. Tie knots in the end if using a 70, as shenanigans may be necessary.
content.location: This route is two bolt lines to the left of Khaleesi

content.description: Nice, straight forward and easy to find warm up for the Grail, main area.
content.protection: 10 bolts to 2 Steel Biners to lower- ( updated )
content.location: Far right of the " Main Wall" area as you approach the cliff. The first bolted line that is vertical in nature. Perhaps 20-30 feet from the actual end of the cliff. Start just above a 3-ft shallow, white ground arch.

content.description:
Start up chert crimps and move right past an awkwardly placed second bolt to an obvious dihedral.  Easier climbing up the shallow corner leads to a final crux just below the anchors on sidepulls and edges. 

  The bolts above the first anchor are an open project.
content.protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Left of Homeostasis by two lines due to a new line called  "Weasel Squeeze" 5.12b at 45m put up in 2018 right between DV and Homeostasis.

content.description: This was the first route up this amazing band of Limestone.   A super 2 pitch outing or well worth doing just the first pitch if your lazy.   P1 Head up the middle of the perfect blue/grey face with miles of great climbing. 5.11c 135ft   P2 Move left and up steep headwall, then trend back right to anchor at the very top of cliff 5.11c 120ft
content.protection: 16 bolts for each pitch. Fixed anchors.   Watch the end of your rope lowering off the first pitch, with a 70m rope IT'S 10 FEET SHORT!! You can swing left to easy scramble down.
content.location: Starts middle of the face between Excalibur and Khaleesi.

content.description: Fairly vertical climbing on not so sharp orange limestone.
content.protection: 8 bolts with an optional 9th, too plus 2 Metolius rap hanger anchors
content.location: Directly left of Eminent Domain, on the main wall wall in Mistys Guide. Very close to the right end of the cliff respectively. Start 1 foot right of a brown & orange, 8-ft, ground-sitting flake.

content.description: Low slope satrting at the stone saddle leads to a tiny finger sized crack for first section.  You don't really climb that crack but it helps identify the route. Seemed easier than 10d, perhaps the moves to the shared anchors with Madame Butterfly and Sweeping Sickness are the harder moves?
content.protection: 10 bolts to shared anchors with the Madame Butterfly and Sweeping Sickness. The 2015 anchors are 3 bolts, 2 of which have rap rings.
content.location: Right of Madame Butterfly in the Alcove area. This climb starts at climbers RIGHT of the small tree/bush in the saddle of the gully. Sort of the rounded arete.

content.description:
A vision quest requiring focus.   Easy climbing up low angle ramp to crux. Tech your way through perfect grey stone and shallow mono pockets with sparse feet to first set of anchors. 

  Then embark on a small hold tech fest with little rest. After a delicate and intricate crux, run it out to the finish. 

  Long climb, sporty on bullet grey rock.
content.protection:
16 bolts 

  P1: 7 bolts to chain anchors with biners. 5.12   p2: 9 bolts to chain anchors with biners. 5.12+

 80m WILL NOT GET YOU DOWN FROM THE TOP.

 You can lower from the top of P2 with a 70m making it to the first set of anchors. 

  TIE A KNOT IN THE ROPE!!
content.location: First route right of Sangreal.   First route left of Swamp King.

content.description: Head up through a vague corner, then move left through some overlaps. The crux is probably between the last bolt and the anchors, moving left again. This route is quite good and it's surprising that it doesn't see much traffic.
content.protection: 7 bolts, ring anchors.
content.location: Just left of the start of Vesper/Air France.

content.description:
A little taste of Southern France. Rock quality and features that are very reminiscent of the Verdon Gorge... right here in the Arizona strip.  

  Start by doing the (right option) first pitch of Vesper. From the comfy belay ledge, take off and mind the gap, following the line of bolts right of Vesper. Some fun, relatively mellow intro climbing leads to a very tricky low angle crux moving left and then up to a line of pockets and then back reaching right to a left facing flake. Take a breather. Either extend this clip and make the clip from below or wait until you're kickin' it at the flake and reach left. 

  The next 3 bolts are the business. Sustained, technical and engaging - sloping pockets, interesting edges and smeary footwork eventually connect you with the second to last bolt on Vesper - finish as you would for Vesper.  

  An outstanding and demanding pitch. A true gem. At some point I would like to lengthen the pitch down into the pit (you'll understand when you get there) but I ran out of bolts and time.. maybe next year...  

  I would highly recommend climbing Vesper first and lowering down this route to hang draws and have a look see at the holds / movement. The last couple clips on this are quite tenuous and a little spicy. Going ground up may result in a handful of jarring, confused falls on a not super rad belay.  

  Grade? Definitely harder than Magnum Opus. But maybe not as hard as Planet Earth (VRG). Maybe the very best rock I've ever touched in North America.
content.protection: 10 bolts. Bring a long runner for the first couple bolts off the belay or back clean them as you climb past.
content.location: To the right of Vesper on the same stunning wall.

content.description:
This wall is the prize! The wall that makes Lime Kiln Canyon famous. Great rock, a variety of quality routes from 5.10- to 5.14a (with a high concentration of quality 5.12's). 70m and even 80m ropes are useful here, and don't miss out on some of the great multipitch lines such as Raven Nation and Vesper. 

  Best routes: 

  Homeostasis 5.11b   City Dweller 5.11d   The Mesquiter 5.12a   Vesper 5.12b   Mantis 5.12c   Homo Faber 5.12d   Honeycomb 5.13a   Hoarse Platitudes 5.13b   Magnum Opus 5.13c-5.14a   Air France 5.14a
